Comment: POHs were restricted because they damaged the broader healthcare system in ways that directly hurt consumers. They cherry-picked the healthiest, most profitable patients, which weakened full-service hospitals that depend on a mix of cases to stay financially viable. POHs generally avoided offering emergency rooms or trauma care, forcing public and nonprofit hospitals to absorb the most expensive, complex cases without the balancing revenue from lower-risk patients. This model disrupted the financial cross-subsidization that hospitals rely on to fund critical but money-losing services like ICUs, emergency departments, and specialized care units. As a result, overall healthcare costs increased, access to comprehensive care shrank, and stability across the system eroded, especially in rural and underserved areas where hospitals operate on thinner margins.  The regulation wasn’t about protecting any one special interest group. It was about stopping a business model that privatized profits and socialized costs, hollowing out the safety-net healthcare infrastructure that everyone ultimately depends on.  Physicians are fully within their rights to own and operate private practices. That has never been restricted, and it is a core part of healthcare in the U.S. The issue is when a private practice seeks hospital status — because hospitals receive significant advantages, including higher Medicare reimbursements, access to public funding mechanisms, and regulatory protections intended for institutions that provide full-spectrum, community-serving care. When private practices are allowed to claim hospital privileges without fulfilling the obligations that come with them, it undermines the entire structure of healthcare delivery, pushing costs up and care availability down for everyone else.

Comment: Title XVIII of the Social Security Act, amended by [Section 6001 of the ACA](https://www.govinfo.gov/content/pkg/PLAW-111publ148/pdf/PLAW-111publ148.pdf), restricts physician-owned hospitals from expanding or billing Medicare if they have self-referral conflicts. The restriction exists because when doctors could refer patients to hospitals they owned, it led directly to cherry-picking, inflated costs, weakened full-service hospitals, and widespread fraud against Medicare and Medicaid. Doctors would offload high-risk, expensive patients onto hospitals they didn’t own, while steering low-risk, high-profit cases into their own facilities. That’s not competition — it’s structured exploitation.  Hospitals and doctors are separated by law to protect consumers. Hospitals aren’t allowed to interfere with medical referrals, and doctors aren't supposed to profit directly from where they send patients. That separation exists for the same reason we restricted pharmaceutical companies from financially influencing doctors’ prescribing habits. When financial interests start dictating medical decisions, consumers lose.  If you want to understand this properly, you can start here:  - [ACA Section 6001 (POH restrictions)](https://www.govinfo.gov/content/pkg/PLAW-111publ148/pdf/PLAW-111publ148.pdf) - [Stark Law - 42 U.S.C. § 1395nn](https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/42/1395nn) - [EMTALA - 42 U.S.C. § 1395dd](https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/42/1395dd) - [Physician Payments Sunshine Act - 42 U.S.C. § 1320a-7h](https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/42/1320a-7h) - [MedPAC Report on POHs (March 2005)](https://www.medpac.gov/wp-content/uploads/import_data/scrape_files/docs/default-source/reports/Mar05_Ch05.pdf) - [MedPAC Report on POHs (June 2010)](https://www.medpac.gov/wp-content/uploads/import_data/scrape_files/docs/default-source/reports/Jun10_Ch02.pdf) - [OIG Reports on POH Fraud and Abuse](https://oig.hhs.gov/)  Repealing these protections without proposing real solutions isn’t reform — it’s deregulating a proven abuse model.  This debate already happened, it was settled for good reason, and I'm not interested in pretending otherwise. If you want to keep arguing, take it up with the actual case law and evidence. I'm done.  This wasn’t just about protecting hospital corporations. CMS, which oversees Medicare and Medicaid, supported the restrictions because they were seeing real abuses and rising costs tied to provider-owned hospitals.  Repealing these protections without offering any solutions would reopen the same problems that justified the regulations in the first place.  Stop arguing about whether this helps or hurts AHA. I don’t care about AHA. I’m talking about the consumer harms, the destabilization of healthcare delivery, and the very real evidence that justified these restrictions decades ago.
